holidays.name: Ask a Stupid Question Day
holidays.description: A day encouraging people to ask questions, no matter how silly they seem, fostering curiosity and learning without fear of judgment.
holidays.origin: Started in 1986 by teachers in the United States to encourage students to speak up and remove the stigma around 'stupid' questions.
holidays.funFact: Teachers observe that students often learn best when they feel safe enough to ask any question, and this day celebrates that spirit of curiosity.

holidays.name: National Skyscraper Day
holidays.description: An ode to the architectural marvels piercing the sky, celebrating human ingenuity in building tall structures that define city skylines worldwide.
holidays.origin: Established to honor the first skyscraper built in Chicago in 1885, marking a turning point in architecture.
holidays.funFact: The first skyscraper, the Home Insurance Building in Chicago, was only 10 stories tall but revolutionized building design with its steel frame.

holidays.name: National Good Neighbor Day
holidays.description: A reminder to appreciate and foster community spirit by being kind and helpful to neighbors near and far.
holidays.origin: Proclaimed in 1978 by President Jimmy Carter to promote neighborly relations and community cooperation.
holidays.funFact: Some towns celebrate this day with block parties and communal meals, strengthening neighborhood bonds.

holidays.name: Eat an Extra Dessert Day
holidays.description: An unofficial but deliciously popular holiday that gives everyone permission to indulge in an extra sweet treat without guilt.
holidays.origin: Popularized in internet culture and food communities as a fun, excuse-to-splurge day.
holidays.funFact: Dessert lovers worldwide celebrate by sharing photos of their favorite extra-helping sweets on social media.
